Dependency injection often comes in two forms:
Applications require a read-only context, which is initialised before the dependent application starts.
Applications require a read/write context, which is initialised before the dependent application starts.

In both cases, the DI runtime guarantees that the context initialisation will occur at the right time — this is the essential guarantee of dependency injection.
Dependency injection is just socially-acceptable global variables — Anon
Personally, I have seen all sorts of gymnastics in an effort to provide this guarantee.
After all, if it is broken at any time, the program crashes spectacularly.
Let's be honest, it never works consistently — it's just a global variable with all the usual dangers. Just sayin'.
OK then, pass arguments through explicitly — clumsy?
